items.content: The Paris criminal court found former French President Nicolas Sarkozy guilty of criminal conspiracy on Thursday, but acquitted him of passive corruption, embezzlement of Libyan public funds, and ille...

items.title: French ex-president Sarkozy convicted for criminal conspiracy in Libyan campaign financing trial
items.standfirst: A Paris court on Thursday convicted former president Nicolas Sarkozy of criminal conspiracy for allegedly accepting illegal campaign funding from late Libyan dictator Moamer Kadhafi during his 2007 presidential bid. He was acquitted of a separate corruption charge, but the judge said he allowed aides to seek financial support for his campaign. Sentencing is pending, with prosecutors seeking a seven-year prison term. FRANCE 24's Philip Turle has more details.
items.content: A Paris court on Thursday convicted former president Nicolas Sarkozy of criminal conspiracy for allegedly accepting illegal campaign funding from late Libyan dictator Moamer Kadhafi during his 2007 presidential bid. He was acquitted of a separate corruption charge, but the judge said he allowed aides to seek financial support for his campaign. Sentencing is pending, with prosecutors seeking a seven-year prison term. FRANCE 24's Philip Turle has more details.

items.title: France ex-President Sarkozy convicted of criminal conspiracy
items.standfirst: Former French president Nicolas Sarkozy was found not guilty of receiving illegal campaign financing from late Libyan dictator Muammar Gaddafi for his successful 2007 presidential bid, but was pronounced guilty of criminal conspiracy in the same case. Sarkozy was acquitted by a Paris court of all other charges, including passive corruption. The court was now set to explain its findings and announce sentencing. FRANCE 24's Claire Paccalin has more from the Paris court.
items.content: Former French president Nicolas Sarkozy was found not guilty of receiving illegal campaign financing from late Libyan dictator Muammar Gaddafi for his successful 2007 presidential bid, but was pronounced guilty of criminal conspiracy in the same case. Sarkozy was acquitted by a Paris court of all other charges, including passive corruption. The court was now set to explain its findings and announce sentencing. FRANCE 24's Claire Paccalin has more from the Paris court.

items.title: French ex-president Sarkozy guilty of conspiracy in Libya campaign case

items.content: Paris criminal court finds Nicolas Sarkozy partly guilty in trial related to alleged campaign funds from Libya.

items.title: Nicolas Sarkozy found guilty of criminal conspiracy in Libya trial
items.standfirst: Former French president cleared of other charges in relation to alleged pact with Gaddafi regimeEurope ‚Äì live updatesThe former French president Nicolas Sarkozy has been found guilty of criminal conspiracy in a trial in which he and aides were accused of making a corruption pact with the regime of the late Libyan dictator Muammar Gaddafi to receive funding for the 2007 French presidential election campaign.But Sarkozy was acquitted of three other charges. As the head judge, Nathalie Gavarino, continued to read the verdict on Thursday, Sarkozy was found guilty of criminal conspiracy but acquitted of corruption, misuse of Libyan public funds and illegal election campaign funding. Sentencing has not yet been announced. Continue reading...
items.content: Former French president cleared of other charges in relation to alleged pact with Gaddafi regimeEurope ‚Äì live updatesThe former French president Nicolas Sarkozy has been found guilty of criminal conspiracy in a trial in which he and aides were accused of making a corruption pact with the regime of the late Libyan dictator Muammar Gaddafi to receive funding for the 2007 French presidential election campaign.But Sarkozy was acquitted of three other charges. As the head judge, Nathalie Gavarino, continued to read the verdict on Thursday, Sarkozy was found guilty of criminal conspiracy but acquitted of corruption, misuse of Libyan public funds and illegal election campaign funding. Sentencing has not yet been announced. Continue reading...

items.title: Sarkozy trial: Everything you need to know

items.title: French ex-president Sarkozy faces verdict over Libya campaign financing

The ruling comes days after the death of a key accuser.

The ruling comes days after the death of a key accuser.

Sarkozy has consistently denied all charges throughout the investigation and trial.

items.content: Mark Cuban says Sinclair and Nexstar's decision to drop Jimmy Kimmel's late-night show could backfire on broadcast TV. Randy Holmes/Disney via Getty Images; AP Photo/David Zalubowski ABC reinstated "Jimmy Kimmel Live!" on Tuesday after suspending the show last week. But Sinclair and Nexstar said‚Ä¶

items.title: Nexstar, joining Sinclair, will preempt Jimmy Kimmel‚Äôs late night show
items.standfirst: The broadcasting group will effectively pull Kimmel‚Äôs show from more than 30 ABC affiliates as the program is set to resume airing Tuesday night.
items.content: Nexstar Media Group will continue to preempt ‚ÄúJimmy Kimmel Live!‚Äù on its ABC affiliates, the company said Tuesday, effectively pulling the late-night show from dozens of local stations as the comedian prepares to make his return to the airwaves. The company noted it would ‚Äúmonitor‚Äù the show as it returns to ABC, but said its stations would ‚Äúfocus on continuing to produce local news and other programming relevant to their respective markets.‚Äù The move makes Nexstar the second broadcasting company to preempt the show, following suit after the Sinclair Broadcasting Group announced Monday it would not air the talk program on its nearly 40 ABC affiliates. ‚ÄúWe made a decision last week to preempt ‚ÄòJimmy Kimmel Live!‚Äô following what ABC referred to as Mr. Kimmel‚Äôs ‚Äòill-timed and insensitive‚Äô comments at a critical time in our national discourse,‚Äù the company wrote in a statement Tuesday. ‚ÄúWe stand by that decision pending assurance that all parties are committed to fostering an environment of respectful, constructive dialogue in the markets we serve.‚Äù Nexstar, the country‚Äôs largest local broadcasting group, owns roughly 30 ABC affiliates across cities like Nashville, Tenn., New Orleans and Salt Lake City. Sinclair also owns dozens of affiliates, including the ABC station serving Washington and its suburbs. ABC parent Disney announced Monday it would resume airing ‚ÄúJimmy Kimmel Live!‚Äù after deciding to suspend the show last week to ‚Äúavoid further inflaming a tense situation at an emotional moment for our country.‚Äù The show‚Äôs suspension sparked a flood of criticism from lawmakers and party leaders across the aisle, citing concerns about censorship ‚Äî particularly after Federal Communications Commission Chair Brendan Carr threatened to look into affiliates because of the comedian‚Äôs comments. Nexstar is currently seeking a merger with Tegna, which requires FCC approval. ‚ÄúWe have spent the last days having thoughtful conversations with Jimmy, and after those conversations, we reached the decision to return the show on Tuesday,‚Äù Disney's statement on Monday read.

ai_summary: Mark Cuban believes the decision to drop Kimmel's show could backfire.
Sinclair and Nexstar are removing Kimmel's show from ABC affiliates.
Kimmel's show resumed airing after a suspension.
The suspension followed Kimmel's comments about Charlie Kirk.
The broadcasting groups are pulling the show from over 30 affiliates.

clusters.title: Weakened Super Typhoon Ragasa heads towards Vietnam after battering China and Hong Kong

bullet_summary: Reported by Guardian World, NBC World

items.title: Weakened Super Typhoon Ragasa heads towards Vietnam after battering China and Hong Kong
items.standfirst: Huge clear-up efforts start after storm leaves trail of destruction, with 25 reported dead in Taiwan and the Philippines Huge clear-up operations were under way in southern China and Hong Kong on Thursday, after Super Typhoon Ragasa battered the region, causing widespread flooding and damaged roads.Ragasa, the most powerful tropical cyclone so far this year, left a trail of damage across Hong Kong, which resumed international flights on Thursday but kept kindergartens and some schools closed. In the economic hub of Guangdong province in mainland China, where more than 2 million people were evacuated ahead of the super typhoon, crews used excavators to clear thousands of toppled trees and unblock roads. Continue reading...

In the economic hub of Guangdong province in mainland China, where more than 2 million people were evacuated ahead of the super typhoon, crews used excavators to clear thousands of toppled trees and unblock roads.
